WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Mrs. Edith Reumann
Address: Spring Valley Park Coop
Birthplace: Fox Lake, Minnesota

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

When year did you start housekeeping in western Canada? 1912
Where did you set up housekeeping? 1887, Spring Valley, Sask.
Where had you been living before that? Lake Louise, Alta.
For how many people did you prepare meals? 12
How far was it to your nearest store? 14 miles, Bayport
How often could a visit be made to the store? Once a week
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flower tea, coffee, rice, baking powder, salt, oatmeal

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Robert Hard & Sons
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 pounds
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $1.89
How much did you use graham flour? None
Whole wheat flour? Some
Was flour milled locally? No
How far away? 42 miles
What year? 1914
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $0.60
What other grain products did you use? Boiled whole wheat
Cornmeal? None
Whole wheat? None
Farina? None
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? By hand

SAXO Reumann, Edith

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

*Breakfast* Serve kind of corned beef coffee Eggs Ham Bread butter Potatoes Vegetable and sometimes pickles Supper tea bread browned up potatoes some meat fruit and sometimes cake.*

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in western Canada? 1912

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

*A regular Xmas dinner minus Turkey.

My family of eight children and some friends Ben Latere age 45. The grandchildren age from 45 to 60. Survived about 20. And some grandchild age from 1 year to 6 cent Remember all. The Henry family. Dan Hagen & wife Wif Bennett & wife - Age about 40 I think. About 35 in all.*

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

For the past several years on sugar tea coffee and tobacco. Used as much of rye grain flour as we could and boiled wheat for breakfast food.
17. Give a typical dinner and breakfast dinner (or supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family still living at the time. Take the approximate number, e.g., what or how many.

Breakfast: Plain fried or corned beef coffee eggs

Dinner: Baked potato, boiled vegetables, and some type of meat

Supper: Tea, bread, butter, potatoes, and some green beans

Coffee and breakfast coffee.

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Today you can get a store dinner all you need is a can opener. Years ago we had to prepare our own food for a year in advance.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

About 1920

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].
Today you can get a store delivered by mail in the preparation of meals in the
kitchen, just as we used to do years ago when food was prepared our own
way for a year or so.

Albert / 1980
